Notes: Starting 25 October schools of all grades have returned to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. While in indoor settings in schools, masks or face coverings are required for all staff and all students in Year 7 and above. Masks are strongly recommended for primary students.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101171544/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families

Starting 8 November all schools in NSW will operate on updated Level 3 settings for the rest of Term. Level 3 is a relaxation of COVID restrictions made of of a combination of layered safety measures allowing student and staff wellness while keeping schools open. This provision has allowed for more school activities including dancing and some music classes, school sports, and now fully vaccinated visitors being allowed on site to support curriculum delivery, wellbeing programs and school operations.    Continuing 25 October policy is still in place where schools of all grades have returned to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. While in indoor settings in schools, masks or face coverings are required for all staff and all students in Year 7 and above. Masks are strongly recommended for primary students.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119173807/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families

Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown. The school and early childhood services are closed. Schools and childcare centres in Katherine will remain open for the children of essential workers only and students doing year 12 exams.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175131/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175313/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

No new policy. Continuing 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. Restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. Workplaces have opened with hygiene or capacity restrictions. Example: up to 75 per cent or up to 30 people can return if total workplace is 40 or less, if thereâs no more than 1 person per 4 square metres for Metropolitan Melbourne locations, and no more than 1 person per 2 square metres for Regional Victoria locations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210708181532/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184508/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/22/melbourne-covid-lockdown-ends-lifts-today-friday-victoria-end-lift-change-what-are-the-new-restrictions-rules-freedoms-reopening-plan  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

Effective Monday 15 November 2021, Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown. This has been extended until Monday, 22 November 2021.    All businesses and community centres are closed. Residents must stay at home for the lockdown period and are only permitted to leave  for work that is considered essential and canât be done at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175131/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175313/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

No new policy. Continuing from 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. However, music festivals still can't be held in NSW.   Other restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. Generally indoor events have a capacity restriction of 75 per cent but outdoor events have 100 per cent capacity with social distancing. Example: A maximum of 2,000 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre assigned a specific seat â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. A maximum of 500 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre allocated to a designated seating area â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. Indoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 75 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises. Outdoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 100 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307062444/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nsw  https://web.archive.org/web/20210708181532/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184508/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/22/melbourne-covid-lockdown-ends-lifts-today-friday-victoria-end-lift-change-what-are-the-new-restrictions-rules-freedoms-reopening-plan  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown.  All businesses and community centres are closed. You can only leave your home for essential reasons including 1) For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house and 2) To provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves or in case of an emergency, including escaping domestic or family violence.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175131/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175313/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

No new policies. Continuing from 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. Restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. The most strict is currently the Victoria region and Metropolitan Melbourne which has a limit of up to 10 people that can visit a home each day (including dependents). Itâs recommended that visitors to homes are fully vaccinated.     For future: Restrictions are expected to ease again once Victoria reaches its 90% fully vaccinated target. Victoria is expected to reach this target on or after 24 November 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102091512/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories (NT) Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown.  You can only leave your home for essential reasons including 1) For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house.    For the rest of NT there's no limit to how many people can gather indoors or outdoors â but you should keep 1.5 metres from people you donât live with. If you need to be closer than 1.5 metres, keep contact to less than 15 minutes at a time. No new policy. Continuing from 16 October a ban exception is travel from the North Island of New Zealand requires quarantine until at least 11:59pm on 31 October 2021. (It was previously banned).      Continuing policy is that Australiaâs borders are currently closed and entry to Australia remains strictly controlled to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Travel to Australia is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption. All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.      https://web.archive.org/web/20211022183326/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022192716/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-international-travellers

Starting 1 Nov Australia's border open after 590 days of restricted access (since March 2020). Fully vaccinated travelers from New Zealand who test negative in pre-departure COVID tests can now enter Australia. They would be allowed to skip quarantine in certain jurisdictions like New South Wales, but those conditions may differ in other states and territories.    Continuing policy for other countries restricts travel to Australia is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption (even if you have been vaccinated). All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094008/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094556/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/international-travel-and-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094513/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/01/australia-reopens-its-borders-to-new-zealand-and-singapore.html

No new policies. Continuing from 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No change.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/dkRj1

No changes.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    People are also encouraged to stay at home through the "Operasi Pulih" programme. No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August. People are required to stay at home, except for essential purposes (for example, going to work for essential workers, buying groceries, or attending funerals and weddings).    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    This is further reiterated under Operasi Pulih, where "The enhanced restrictions to limit movement between 8pm to 4am announced yesterday under Operasi Pulih (Recovery Operation) is aimed at stopping the public from going out to visit and gather with others, with the exception of essential workers who need to go out to work for the good of society.    This was shared by Minister at the Prime Ministerâs Office and Minister of Finance and Economy II Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mohd Amin Liew bin Abdullah during a press conference yesterday, in addition to the strengthening of enforcement agenciesâ activities and public cooperation in aiding the government through the newly introduced 24-hour hotline, as well as involvement of penghulus and village heads in monitoring residents, which are important to ensure people reduce movement."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Pulih published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 05 Nov, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/1kUfS  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/LLpFZ  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 18 Nov, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration. No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 03 Nov (https://archive.vn/7Jl7F) and 04 Nov (https://archive.vn/H51Ij).    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 05 Nov,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/1kUfS  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 05 Nov,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/1kUfS

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot". No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." The potential public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, globally, nationally, and to our island. Individual risk is dependent on exposure. Everyone in our community can take steps now to prepare for this emerging public health threat by doing everyday preventative measures:     Itâs currently flu and respiratory disease season and CDC recommends getting a flu vaccine, taking everyday preventive actions to help stop the spread of germs, and taking flu antivirals if prescribed.  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. However, if soap and water are not readily available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.  Avoid touching your mouth, eyes, and nose with unwashed hands.  Avoid close contact with people who are sick.  Practice proper cough etiquette â cover your mouth and nose with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects or surfaces.  Stay home when you are sick â do not go to work or school.    /web/20211108201920/https://www.grta.guam.gov/precautionary-measures-department-public-health

/web/20211108214742/https://guamrecovery.com/employee-information-programs-assistance/  New LEAP programme offers loan only, not income relief   The PUA program, in general, provides up to 39 weeks of unemployment benefits. Guamâs PUA Weekly Benefit Amount (WBA) is $345 a week. Employees who have been laid off or furloughed due to COVID-19 qualify for the full amount. Employees still working but making less than $345 a week qualify for PUA minus their wages. Those making $345 or more do not qualify for PUA.

Pfizer and Moderna has also been given for booster and additional doses    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023001801/https:/www.ghs.guam.gov/jic-release-no-808-covid-19-updates-57-hospitalized-preliminary-test-results-84-new-cases-pfizer

/web/20211108213047/https://guamrecovery.com/79-new-cases-46-hospitalized-community-reminded-to-continue-wearing-face-masks/     Covid-19 vaccines available, boosters available as below:   FREE COVID-19 BOOSTER VACCINATION VILLAGE CLINICS (for 65 and older) Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson  For individuals who received a Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine (first two doses), the following groups are eligible for a booster shot at 6 months or more after their initial series:    Anyone age 65 years and older  Anyone age 18 years and older with underlying medical conditions  Anyone 18 years and older with an elevated risk of COVID-19 exposure and transmission due to their occupation (e.g. healthcare workers, law enforcement, fire, K-12 teachers and support staff, university faculty, daycare employees, food and agriculture workers, manufacturing workers, USPS workers, corrections workers, public transit workers, grocery store workers) or institutional settings.  For individuals who received the Johnson and Johnson/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, booster shots are also recommended for those who are 18 and older and who were vaccinated two or more months ago.

No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and continues undergoing a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Increased ventilation measures and distribution of antigen test kits will also continue to be conducted. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo until Oct 24)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023053608/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/020/469/20210928/20211021.pdf (Tokyo Oct 25-31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa until Oct 31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233400/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

All precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures.  Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis. On October 25, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, and Kanagawa.  On November 1, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service will be lifted in Okinawa.    All businesses in Okinawa including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 7:00PM in Okinawa.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023053608/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/020/469/20210928/20211021.pdf (Tokyo Oct 25-31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa until Oct 31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233400/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

On November 1, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in Okinawa, the final prefectural call for shorten business hours.    Infection control continue to be recommended for all businesses, however no closures are in place for any industry. Businesses are also recommended to continue working from home (telework) if able, expand staggered commuting, and take other measures to prevent denseness during commuting and work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106032948/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034454/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034435/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

On October 25, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, and Kanagawa.  On November 1, time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service will be lifted in Okinawa.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity or an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Tokyo and Okinawa, events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses in Okinawa are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233011/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023053608/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/020/469/20210928/20211021.pdf (Tokyo Oct 25-31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa until Oct 31)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233400/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. However, if necessary, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event holders may also consult directly with city or prefectural authorities to safely hold the event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106032948/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034454/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034435/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

No change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation. Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001901/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023062858/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C129.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001917/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

The government announces Japan will begin permitting entry of international students and shortening the quarantine period to 3-days for fully vaccinated individuals on business trips beginning November 8.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106040544/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211105/k10013336361000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001901/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041201/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C138.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041008/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

On November 8, Japan has shortenedthe quarantine period to 3-days for all incoming fully vaccinated travellers. International students on scolarships with Japanese universities are also permitted to enter Japan. However, The government continues to limit the number of people allowed to enter the country per day to 3,500, including Japanese citizens.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5). No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041348/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002518/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy.  Rapid antigen tests are freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002805/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002808/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002840/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/

In preparation of wave 6 of infections, the government is considering offering free PCR and rapid antigen testing to all individuals including those who are asymptomatic. However, as of now, only symptomatic and those in close contact with a positive case are eligible for free testing.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.  Rapid antigen tests are also freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041522/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050713/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050801/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/

On November 12, the Japanese government announces change in testing policy. As a pre-emptive measure in preparations for countering against a sixth wave of infection, free PCR and antigen testing have become available for asymptomatic individuals.    Despite the announcement we cannot find any firm dates when the policy comes in to force. Should dates become clearer at a leter date we will adjust the policy accordingly.    Kishida announced Friday that, while new cases are rising, individuals who canât be vaccinated for health reasons and who donât have symptoms but are concerned they have been infected can receive a PCR or antigen test before taking part in certain economic or social activities.    The plan is part of a greater effort to prepare the country for a sixth wave of the pandemic â and whatever comes afterwards â by bolstering hospitals, procuring more medical staff, expanding its vaccine campaign, administering booster shots and advancing the treatment of those with COVID-19.    âWhile new cases have declined substantially, itâs important to acknowledge the strong possibility that the virus will return and to prepare accordingly,â Kishida said Friday.    Itâs not exactly clear who will be eligible and under what circumstances, but Kishida said Friday that the decision will be left to local governments, who have been directed to execute the plan at the latest by the end of March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114022125/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/12/national/covid19-policies-free-testing/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050612/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/politics/20211107-OYT1T50148/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050745/https://toyokeizai.net/articles/-/469112  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042821/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013349111000.html (logistics for free asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050557/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119045214/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

No change to previous policy.  While infection rates continue to decrease in Tokyo, it was reported on Oct 20 that 60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. Experts however urge the city to thoroughly investigate infection routes now that cases are low.  Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003031/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    In Osaka, Minami city, after calls for shortened business hours were lifted for restaurants on Oct 25, the city is testing out logistics for vaccination passports until Oct 29.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004334/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211025/k10013321141000.html (vaccination passport in Minami)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003759/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004155/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

The government announces vaccination for 5-11 year olds are currently under the review process and is expected to begin February 2022 at the earliest.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044541/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211117/k10013351001000.html (5-11 year olds)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044634/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013348971000.html (non-Japanese speakers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of October 5, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003529/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003536/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003632/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/

From Nov 1, schools at all levels across Cambodia have been reopened after 13.7 million people, or 85.68 percent of the country's 16-million population, have been inoculated with COVID-19 vaccines.    However, strict rules regarding covid are implemented including "standard operating procedures and other health safety measures, the number of students in each class is limited to not more than 15, and they must sit at least 1.5 meters away from each other in order to keep social distancing" etc.     link: https://archive.ph/wlbST  link: https://archive.ph/1uyp4

No change in policies.   "Certain businesses deemed at a high risk of transmitting the virus such as entertainment complexes have been ordered closed in some provinces. (effective from 18th October)" - especially in some "red zone" areas. For example, in Phnom Penh (29-Oct-2021 to 11-Nov-2021), the procedure is extended for a week. "1. Suspend all businesses that are high risk of Covid:  - All kinds of entertainment club businesses ex karaoke, discotheque, cinemas and bars 2. Businesses not suspended must strictly adhere to safety measures (3 do's/3 don'ts) and sanitization"    link: https://archive.ph/Y4JRe  link: https://archive.ph/cV34B

No change in policy. Stricter rules exist in high-risk areas.  For example, in Mondulkiri Province, "effective 14-June-2021 Admin Measures - No Expiry Ban on Sports/Gyms + Ban on Gatherings of more than 5 people + Ban on Dine-In". This is a stricter target requirement that extended into Nov.    link: https://archive.ph/Y4JRe  link: https://archive.ph/cV34B

No change in policies. Red zones restrictions are lifted but according to the local map, for example, in Stung Treng Province, from 31-August-2021 until further notice, "Continued Administrative Measures in Stung Treng Province including temporary suspension of business activities and business of: Curfew 9pm to 3am". [This restriction is still valid in November.]    link: https://archive.ph/Y4JRe  link: https://archive.ph/cV34B
Under current lockdown, travel through these âRed Zonesâ is not permitted.    link: https://archive.ph/cV34B

The Curfew Order introduced in July 2021, which refers to restrictions on gatherings, continues to be listed under official Government pages with no further update ( http://archive.today/2021.09.30-061704/https://www.president.gov.ki/resources/gazettes-instruments.html ), however there are no recent references to this curfew order or restrictions on gatherings in official facebook pages.  Photographs of gatherings from Facebook pages do not suggest that this order is current and the Police department page (https://www.facebook.com/kiribatipolice) makes no reference to infringement or enforcement of this order.

No").  Although references were made to the curfew order on the police facebook page on 28th July and 2nd August 2021, no further references have been identified since then.  It is therefore unclear whether the curfew remains in place.

Education Minister Yoo Eun-hye announced new measures Friday to allow all kindergarten to high school students to fully attend schools from Nov. 22, and universities to gradually expand face-to-face lectures from Monday.  https://archive.md/MRKeg

Clubs and bars that allow dancing will be required to close at midnight, and even that will be lifted in the second phase set to begin around mid-December. Curfew on hagwon (cram schools), set at 10 p.m. in the greater Seoul area, will be lifted from Nov. 22, after the Korean CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test). The greater Seoul area consists of Seoul, Gyeonggi and Incheon.  https://archive.md/MRKeg

Mass events, including conferences, weddings, funerals and birthday parties for one-year-olds, a common Korean custom, will be limited to 100 people if they include unvaccinated people. If everyone has a vaccine pass or a recent negative test, the cap will be eased to 499 people.    https://archive.md/MRKeg

Social gatherings will be allowed for up to 10 people in the greater Seoul area and up to 12 people in other regions, regardless of vaccination status. In restaurants and cafes, however, unvaccinated people will be limited to gatherings of four.  https://archive.md/MRKeg

Mask wearing requirements:  Macau requires the wearing of a face mask in many public settings including, banks, casinos, and on public transportation. No policy change. Macau Health App still in force    https://web.archive.org/web/20211116185742/https://hk.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Movement Restrictions:    Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Social distancing requirements:  The Macau government requires the use of the Macau Health Code for entrance to certain locations like immigration buildings, medical institutions, casinos, hotels, and guesthouses. Similarly, temperature checks are mandatory in many settings. For more details, please see the Macau governmentâs COVID-19 website.  As part of the Government of Macauâs declaration of a state of immediate pandemic prevention on September 25, 2021, many regular services in Macau were suspended. The declaration on October 4, 2021 means most of these suspensions will continue. Education institutions, set to resume classes on October 3, 2021, will now be suspended until further notice.  Schools may launch home learning according to their own discretion. The Social Welfare Bureau will continue to suspend the operation of subsidized nursery facilities, non-residential and non-emergency social facilities. Residential homes and emergency support services will remain open during this period. See this government press release for more information. On September 25, 2021, ferry services between Macau and Shenzhen and Macau and Zhuhaiâs Wanzai Port were suspended until further notice. Beginning October 6, 2021, certain recreational facilities like cinemas, theatres, indoor amusement parks, game centers, cybercafes, billiard rooms, bowling centers, saunas, massage parlors, beauty salons, gyms, health clubs, karaoke lounges, bars, nightclubs, discotheques, dance parlors, and cabaret venues will be closed. To learn more about closures or cancellations of other Macau services, please check back on the Macau governmentâs website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211116185742/https://hk.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry to Macao  The Macao government has announced that all travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller. You can find further information by visiting the Macao Government Tourism Board website.    Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China who have travelled overseas in the 21 days prior to their arrival will also be denied entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211006191551/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/macao/entry-requirements

According the IMF, as of 30 June 2021, cash income support is still being offerd through the Wealth Partaking Scheme, in addition to electronic vouchers intended to encourage local spending.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106175136/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

According the IMF, as of 30 June 2021, tax-relief and tax-exemption measures amounting to 1.1 billion patacas, or 0.5 percent of GDP are still in effect.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106175136/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Individuals may book an appointment at one of Macauâs approved COVID-19 testing locations. Some testing locations allow Macau residents a free first test, while others charge 100 MOP. Test results are provided via email and SMS. For more information on COVID-19 testing, please see the Macau governmentâs website. Testing locations can be found under âNucleic Acid Test of COVID-19â tab of the Macau governmentâs COVID site homepage.  In cases of âimmediate pandemic prevention statusâ, to secure public order, safety, and health the Macau government may mandate that 100% of the population undergo COVID-19 testing. The Macau government has launched mass testing in response to new positive COVID cases on three different occasions, from August 4 to August 10, 2021, September 25 to September 28, 2021, and October 4 to October 7, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211116185742/https://hk.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Macau Health App is used to enter a vast range of buildings and provide status on individuals    Public spaces and services  Macao has introduced a QR three-colour code system, which replaces the previous digital health declaration needed at border checkpoints and for entering public administration premises, casinos and other venues. The new code requires its users to confirm whether they have been in COVID-19 quarantine at home or in a government-run facility and consists of three colours: red, yellow, green. Visitors receiving red or yellow codes may be subject to testing, hospitalisation or restrictions on their movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211006190719/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/macao/coronavirus

Mask wearing requirements:  Macau requires the wearing of a face mask in many public settings including, banks, casinos, and on public transportation. The Social Security Board, under the Ministry of Labor, Immigration and Population, will pay 40 percent of the salary to insured workers, as a family assistance fund, in accordance with the Social Security Law. Insured workers who are included in the Stay-at-Home order and worked at the private factories and businesses as of September 23 are entitled to this benefit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211108233222/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Contact tracing is being done    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034039/https://mohs.gov.mm/page/8509    The Ministry of Health and Sports is conducting disease surveillance and surveillance activities to identify those who have been in close contact with laboratory-confirmed patients for the prevention and control of COVID-19 disease. In doing so, we are identifying those who have been in close contact with the patient for 2 days before the onset of symptoms and within 14 days after the onset of symptoms, based on the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHOID).  ??????? The laboratory-confirmed patients and their families and their places of residence; People who worked together Close contacts Strict home quarantine is being monitored for those who travel together during the trip. The participation of all members of the public, including family members, is especially needed in such monitoring.  ??????? Therefore, the Ministry of Health and Sports is announcing the visit to public places within 2 days before the onset of symptoms and 14 days after the onset of the symptoms of laboratory confirmation patients, and urges the public who have been in contact with these patients to contact the nearest administration and health department as soon as possible.
Face masks must be worn at all times outside the home    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101095550/https:/mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Upper Northland - alert 3  Auckland - alert 3, step 1  Parts of Waikato - level 3, step 2  The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2.     For level 3 children and young people should learn from home. Early learning centres can open to provide childcare for children whose parents need to go into work. Play centres and playgroups must close. All tertiary education providers should deliver their courses online.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211108142432/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/

Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.     The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    Schools  Akonga (students) in Years 11, 12 and 13 in Alert Level 3 areas are able to return to school. Akonga who are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should continue to learn from home, unless they are fully vaccinated.    Tamariki (children) and rangatahi (young people) in Years 1 to 10 should continue to learn from home â unless their parents or carers need to go to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/

Upper Northland - alert 3  Auckland - alert 3, step 1  Parts of Waikato - level 3, step 2  The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2.   Level 3 - You should work from home if you can (Auckland, Northland and parts of Waikato).    Level 2 - you can go to work, and all businesses and services can open but must follow public health rules. These include physical distancing, some workers wearing face coverings, and displaying the NZ COVID Tracer QR code (rest of New Zealand)    http://web.archive.org/web/20211108142432/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/

Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.   The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    At Step 2, retail can open, with customers keeping 2 metres apart. Staff and customers are required to wear face coverings. Outdoor organised exercise classes, like yoga and bootcamps, can expand to 25 people (including instructors), with 2-metre physical distancing required.    At Step 2, customers cannot enter business premises to consume food, regardless of whether they are seated indoors or outdoors, or if they are bringing their own food.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/

Upper Northland - alert 3  Auckland - alert 3, step 1  Parts of Waikato - level 3, step 2  The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2.     Level 3: Events cannot go ahead. The only gatherings allowed are weddings, civil unions, funerals and tangihanga. All public facilities and venues such as museums, cinemas, libraries and swimming pools must close (Auckland, Northland and parts of Waikato).    Level 2 - There are no restrictions on the number of people that can attend an event at a venue, for example at a stadium, cinema, theatre or conference venue â as long as everyone can safely stay 1 metre apart (rest of New Zealand)    http://web.archive.org/web/20211108142432/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/

Events cannot go ahead. The only gatherings allowed at Alert Level 3 are weddings, civil unions, funerals and tangihanga with restrictions on numbers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119002127/https://covid19.govt.nz/activities/events-and-entertainment/

Upper Northland - alert 3  Auckland - alert 3, step 1  Parts of Waikato - level 3, step 2  The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211108142432/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/    Level 3 you cannot meet outside of your bubble.  Auckland remains at Alert Level 3. People in Auckland can now meet up with friends and whanau who are not in their household. There are some restrictions:    You can meet 1 other household at a time, up to a maximum of 10 people.  You must meet outside, and maintain physical distancing.    At Alert Level 2, you can host or attend a gathering of up to 100 people in any defined indoor or outdoor space.

Auckland - Alert 3 Step 2    Outdoor gatherings of up to 25 people (up from 10) can go ahead. This is no longer restricted to 2 households only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/

Under Level 4 alert: "The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Residents aged below 18 or above 65 years old, as well as pregnant and immunocompromised people, must remain at home in all areas. Nonessential tourist attractions and entertainment venues are closed. Meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) are not allowed. Non-essential social gatherings are banned. Food establishments may offer indoor and outdoor dine-in services at varying capacity limits; only fully vaccinated individuals can dine in. Businesses with the Safety Seal certification are allowed to operate at an additional 10 percent capacity."    link: https://archive.ph/MW7yT

No change in policy.    Under the MECQ, strictest regulations currently in place, public transport is suspended. However, point-to-point transport services provided by the government shall be allowed to operate, giving priority to healthcare worlers. While, commissioned shuttle services and personal vehicles of employees of permitted establishments are allowed, subject to guidelines provided by Dpt of Transportation. The movement of cargo vehicles shall be unhampered. Bikes and other non-motorized transportation are strongly encourages.     link: https://archive.ph/kSUdj

No change in policy.    Under the MECQ, strictest guidelines currently applied, strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households. Residents can only step out to access essential goods and services and work in permitted offices and establishments. The following people are not allowed to go outside: people below 21, people 60 and above, persons with disabilities and other health risks, pregnant women, any person who rside with the aforementioned.    Under the alert level 4 zones: The following persons shall not be allowed outside of their respective residences: (i) persons below eighteen (18) years old, (ii) those who are over sixty-five years (65) of age, (iii) those with immunodeficiencies, comorbidities, or other health risks, and (iv) pregnant women; provided, that they shall be allowed access to obtain essential goods and services, or for work in permitted industries and offices.    link: https://archive.ph/kSUdj  link: https://archive.ph/MW7yT

No change in policy.    Nothing found for the MECQ regarding internal movement. However, the lockdown rules would mean it is prohibited.     Under alert level 4 zones : Intrazonal and interzonal travel for persons not otherwise required to remain at their residences in the preceding paragraph may be allowed subject to the reasonable regulations of the LGU of destination. This applies to cities/municipalities.    In areas under Alert Level 3: "Movement is allowed but restrictions may be imposed."    link: https://archive.ph/kSUdj  link: https://archive.ph/MW7yT  link: https://archive.ph/DoVbV

Classes in day schools in East New Britain will be reduced to 3 days a week starting Oct 29 until Nov 14. Elementary and vocational schools will have no classes. Boarding schools and tertiary institutions will continue    Some schools in Western Highlands remain closed as part of a 2 week lockdown started on Oct 18    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031075640/https:/www.thenational.com.pg/enb-schools-reduce-classes-to-stop-spread-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031082047/https:/postcourier.com.pg/two-week-lockdown-for-whp/

Classes in day schools in East New Britain will be reduced to 3 days a week starting Oct 29 until Nov 14. Elementary and vocational schools will have no classes. Boarding schools and tertiary institutions will continue    Some schools in Western Highlands remain closed as part of a 2 week lockdown started on Oct 18    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031075640/https:/www.thenational.com.pg/enb-schools-reduce-classes-to-stop-spread-of-covid-19/

SCHOOLS in East New Britain (ENB) are to reduce classes to three days a week in a bid to control and contain the surge of the Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic.  The reduction is effective today for 14 days.  Administrator Wilson Matava, in a circular, said the containment would end on Nov 14.  âThe intent of the containment is to arrest the increasing Covid-19 cases in the province by controlling the unnecessary movement of people,â he said.  âEducation is an essential service.  âHowever, classes for day schools will be limited to three days per week, while teachers attend work as normal for five days.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211115152032/https://www.thenational.com.pg/enb-schools-reduce-classes-to-stop-spread-of-covid-19/

Western Highlands in going into a 2 week lockdown starting Oct 18. Business houses will operate from 7 am to 4 pm.   Mount Hagen, Kaiwe and other smaller markets will close. Schools have been reopening in phases and have now introduced regular ART testing regimen until the year end school holidays in mid november.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Primary school pupils will need to take an antigen rapid test (ART) every two weeks until school closes for the holidays in November, said the Ministry of Education (MOE).  In a letter addressed to parents and guardians on digital portal Parents Gateway on Wednesday (Oct 20), MOE said 10 ART kits will be distributed to each pupil from next Monday.  That means parents will not need to buy more ART kits for their children."
